# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. Á¶ÅÊ≠¢‰∫ãÈ†ÖÁ¢∫Ë™ç: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl ‚Üí Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py ‚Üí Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log ‚Üí Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

### ÂøÖË¶Å„Å™ÁÖ©Èõë„ÅïÔºàÊú¨Ë≥™ÁöÑË§áÈõëÊÄßÔºâ
- **„Éù„Éº„ÉàÁÆ°ÁêÜ**: „ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÁí∞Â¢É„Åß„ÅÆ„Éù„Éº„ÉàÁ´∂ÂêàÂõûÈÅø
- **„Éá„Éº„Çø„Éô„Éº„ÇπÂàùÊúüÂåñ**: „ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÁî®„ÅÆÁã¨Á´ã„Åó„ÅüDBÁí∞Â¢É
- **ÈùûÂêåÊúüÂæÖÊ©ü**: „Çµ„Éº„Éê„ÉºËµ∑ÂãïÂÆå‰∫Ü„ÅÆÁ¢∫Ë™ç

### ‰∏çË¶Å„Å™ÁÖ©Èõë„ÅïÔºàÂÅ∂Áô∫ÁöÑË§áÈõëÊÄßÔºâ
- **ÊâãÂãï„Éó„É≠„Çª„ÇπÁÆ°ÁêÜ**: kill/restart „ÅÆÊâã‰ΩúÊ•≠
- **Áí∞Â¢ÉÂ§âÊï∞„ÅÆÊï£Âú®**: Ë®≠ÂÆö„ÅåË§áÊï∞ÁÆáÊâÄ„Å´ÂàÜÊï£
- **„ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÈ†ÜÂ∫è‰æùÂ≠ò**: Ââç„ÅÆ„ÉÜ„Çπ„Éà„ÅÆÂΩ±Èüø„ÇíÂèó„Åë„Çã

### ÂÆü„ÅØ„Ç∑„É≥„Éó„É´„Å´„Åß„Åç„ÇãÊñπÊ≥ï

```nix
# flake.nix „ÅÆ checks „Çª„ÇØ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥
checks.e2e = pkgs.writeShellScriptBin "e2e-test" ''
  # 1. „ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÁî®„Çµ„Éº„Éê„Éº„Çí‰∏ÄÊôÇ„Éù„Éº„Éà„ÅßËµ∑Âãï
  PORT=$(shuf -i 10000-20000 -n 1)
  
  # 2. „Çµ„Éº„Éê„ÉºËµ∑Âãï„Å®„Éò„É´„Çπ„ÉÅ„Çß„ÉÉ„ÇØ
  timeout 30 bash -c "
    ${self.packages.server}/bin/server --port=$PORT &
    SERVER_PID=$!
    
    # Ëµ∑ÂãïÂæÖÊ©üÔºà„Éò„É´„Çπ„ÉÅ„Çß„ÉÉ„ÇØÔºâ
    until curl -s localhost:$PORT/health; do
      sleep 0.1
    done
    
    # 3. e2e„ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÂÆüË°å
    ${pkgs.pytest}/bin/pytest tests/e2e --base-url=http://localhost:$PORT
    
    # 4. Ëá™Âãï„ÇØ„É™„Éº„É≥„Ç¢„ÉÉ„Éó
    kill $SERVER_PID
  "
'';
```

„Åì„Çå„Åß `nix flake check` „Å†„Åë„ÅßÂÖ®„Å¶„ÅåÂÆåÁµê„Åó„Åæ„Åô„ÄÇÁÖ©Èõë„Åï„ÅØ„ÄåË®≠ÂÆö„ÅÆ‰∏ÄÂÖÉÂåñ„Äç„ÅßËß£Ê∂à„Åß„Åç„ÇãÂÅΩÁâ©„ÅÆÂïèÈ°å„Åß„Åó„Åü„ÄÇ

content.content:
1‚ÜíI‚Äôve been using Nix / NixOS for a couple years now, but have never really bothered to learn the NixOS testing framework. After playing with it a bit, I really like it!
     2‚ÜíIt‚Äôs like all the best properties of classic Vagrant and Chef Test Kitchen, but with the power and reproducibility of Nix.
     3‚Üí
     4‚Üí[Andreas Fuchs‚Äô blogged](https://boinkor.net/2024/02/saved-by-nixos-integration-tests-surprisingly/) about how NixOS tests actually helped them catch a regression in their code, so I felt inspired to give it a try.
     5‚Üí
     6‚ÜíSince I use nix flakes for all my personal development and machine setup, and the [Nix documentation](https://nixos.org/manual/nixos/stable/index.html#sec-nixos-tests) doesn‚Äôt go into detail about
     7‚Üíhow to use the NixOS test harness with flakes, I wrote up my initial investigation here.
     8‚Üí
     9‚ÜíThis setup will allow us to:
    10‚Üí
    11‚Üí1. Build a custom package with nix flakes.
    12‚Üí1. Run that package as a NixOS systemd service via a NixOS module.
    13‚Üí1. Boot a QEMU machine and execute automated tests against the package / module configuration.
    14‚Üí
    15‚ÜíBecause it‚Äôs Nix, the entire process of building the package, assembling it into a systemd service, booting a QEMU VM, and executing tests all happens
    16‚Üíwith a single command with a declarative build definition.
    17‚Üí
    18‚ÜíFirst, setup a bare-bones flake with a custom package. For this example, we‚Äôll just make a simple `netcat` echo server that listens on port 3000.
    19‚Üí
    20‚Üí**flake.nix**
    21‚Üí
    22‚Üí```nix
    23‚Üí{
    24‚Üí  description = "NixOS tests example";
    25‚Üí
    26‚Üí  inputs = {
    27‚Üí    nixpkgs.url = "github:nixos/nixpkgs/nixos-23.11";
    28‚Üí    flake-utils.url = "github:numtide/flake-utils";
    29‚Üí  };
    30‚Üí
    31‚Üí  outputs = { self, nixpkgs, flake-utils }:
    32‚Üí    flake-utils.lib.eachDefaultSystem (system:
    33‚Üí      let
    34‚Üí        pkgs = nixpkgs.legacyPackages.${system};
    35‚Üí      in
    36‚Üí        {
    37‚Üí          packages = {
    38‚Üí            helloNixosTests = pkgs.writeScriptBin "hello-nixos-tests" ''
    39‚Üí            ${pkgs.netcat}/bin/nc -l 3000
    40‚Üí            '';
    41‚Üí          };
    42‚Üí        }
    43‚Üí    );
    44‚Üí}
    45‚Üí``` Once you save your `flake.nix` file, you should be able to build the package from within the directory:
    46‚Üí
    47‚Üí```
    48‚Üí$ nix build '.#helloNixosTests'
    49‚Üí$ ./result/bin/hello-nixos-tests
    50‚Üí```

08 Jan 2023

# How to use NixOS testing framework with flakes

J√∂rg Thalheim and Alex A. Renoire

In this article, I will explain how to perform full integration tests with
flakes outside nixpkgs.

With [NixOS testing framework](https://wiki.nixos.org/wiki/NixOS_Testing_library),
you can
[create end-to-end integration tests](https://nix.dev/tutorials/integration-testing-using-virtual-machines)
easily. It all comes down to starting a virtual machine based on your custom
modules and testing its state with a Python script. This way, you can identify
in advance all the regressions and incompatible configurations arising from the
updates you introduced.

One of the framework ‚Äô s upsides is that it ‚Äô s extremely fast ‚Äî maybe the fastest
of its kind: setting up VMs and running tests does not take much time thanks to
sharing files with the nix store on the host.

But previously, there was no stable API to import the testing framework into
projects, therefore it was hard to test anything that ‚Äô s outside NixOS. The
situation has changed thanks to Robert Hensing, who \[created a new modular
interface\] for testing.

But there ‚Äô s still a problem with documentation. Of course, you can refer to the
corresponding
[manual chapter](https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/blob/master/nixos/doc/manual/development/writing-nixos-tests.section.md)
to explore NixOS testing framework. But many topics aren ‚Äô t explained in detail,
so I decided to write a brief intro to testing NixOS modules with flakes.

# Intro to testing in NixOS

Let me give you some info on how tests are executed, and how to incorporate them
into your project. If you ‚Äô re new to NixOS, this info may be helpful.

So, how are tests executed in NixOS? To verify that the flake can be evaluated
successfully, we run the
[flake check](https://nixos.org/manual/nix/stable/command-ref/new-cli/nix3-flake-check.html)
command. Under the hood, nix will run the so-called test driver in its own build
sandbox. The test driver provides an API for the test script to setup virtual
machines. When the VMs are ready, a series of tests are executed to check if
NixOS modules are functioning as intended.

That ‚Äô s a very broad outlook on how tests work. But how do you write tests?
First, if you are testing a module outside NixOS, i.e. in your own project, you
have to import `nixpkgs`, the biggest repository of Nix packages where the
testing library is located.

There are several ways to import `nixpkgs` in your code. One way is via
`fetchTarball`:

```nix
{
  nixpkgs = fetchTarball "https://github.com/NixOS/nixpkgs/archive/....tar.gz";
  pkgs = import nixpkgs {};
}
```

But `fetchTarball` is a builtin, which means that `nixpkgs` will be downloaded
during evaluation. Another way is to load `nixpkgs` using a
[flake](https://wiki.nixos.org/wiki/Flakes). It ‚Äô s more convenient, because this way
you can update the dependencies easily. I ‚Äô ll use this approach in my example.

Let ‚Äô s move to the coding part now.

# Defining a flake to be tested

As an example, I‚Äôll take a simple project that runs a web server returning a
‚ÄúHello world!‚Äù string. First, let‚Äôs specify the flake:

```nix
# flake.nix
{
  inputs.nixpkgs.url = "github:nixos/nixpkgs/nixpkgs-unstable";
  outputs = { self, nixpkgs, ...}: {
    nixosModules.hello-world-server = import ./hello-world-server.nix {};
  };
}
```

This flake exposes the module `./hello-world-server.nix`. You can find the file
in the repository [here](https://github.com/Mic92/nixos-test-example). What it
does is it creates a simple HTML page and starts a server on the port 8000. The
correct behavior would be if the module returns a ‚ÄúHello world!‚Äù string. Any
other output will be incorrect.

# Writing the tests

Now that we have our flake and module, we can write a test to check if we can
reach the server.

But before that, we will create a helper function in `./tests/lib.nix`, which
will import the testing framework from nixpkgs. Extending `specialArgs` will
allow us to pass through any flake inputs and outputs.

```nix
# tests/lib.nix
# The first argument to this function is the test module itself

content.text:
# /commit - Git commit only Claude-edited files

## Purpose
Commit only the files that you (Claude) have edited in the current session, excluding any files modified by others.

## Usage
When the user says "commit", "/commit", or mentions "git commit":

0. Á¶ÅÊ≠¢‰∫ãÈ†ÖÁ¢∫Ë™ç: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. First run `git status` to see all changed files
2. Identify which files you have edited during this conversation
3. Stage ONLY those files you edited
4. Create a commit with a descriptive message
5. Ensure no other files are accidentally included
6. After commit, check for remaining uncommitted files in current directory (pwd) only
7. If uncommitted files exist in pwd, explain why they weren't included

## Important Rules
- NEVER commit files you didn't edit
- Always verify staged files before committing
- Use the commit message format from bin/docs/conventions/commit_messages.md
- Include the Claude signature in commit messages

## Example Flow
```bash
# 1. Check status
git status

# 2. Reset all staged files
git reset HEAD

# 3. Add only your edited files
git add path/to/your-file1.txt
git add path/to/your-file2.py

# 4. Verify staged files
git status

# 5. Commit with proper message
git commit -m "feat: implement new feature

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.ai/code)

Co-Authored-By: Claude <noreply@anthropic.com>"

# 6. Check for remaining changes in current directory only
git status .

# 7. If uncommitted files exist, explain each:
# - .claude/projects/*.jsonl ‚Üí Session tracking files (not my edits)
# - bin/src/other/file.py ‚Üí Modified by another developer/tool
# - test_output.log ‚Üí Generated file (not source code)
```

## Post-Commit Analysis
After committing, analyze remaining uncommitted files in the current directory (pwd) only:

### Check scope:
- Use `git status .` to check only files in current directory and subdirectories
- Ignore files outside of pwd to focus on relevant changes
- This prevents unnecessary analysis of unrelated project files

### Common reasons for uncommitted files:
1. **Session tracking files** (`.claude/projects/*.jsonl`) - Automatic session logs
2. **Other developer's work** - Files modified by team members or other tools
3. **Generated files** - Build outputs, logs, temporary files
4. **Unrelated changes** - Files outside current task scope
5. **Incomplete work** - Files requiring further modifications

### Working directory focus:
- Only analyze files within pwd and its subdirectories
- Example: If pwd is `/home/nixos/bin/src/poc/`, only check that path
- Skip global repository status to maintain focused analysis

## Key Principle
"Commit only your files except for others" - This ensures clean commit history and prevents accidental inclusion of work done by other developers or tools.

## ÂÆåÂÖ®„Å´ÂèØËÉΩ„Åß„ÅôÔºÅ

NixOS„ÉÜ„Çπ„Éà„Éï„É¨„Éº„É†„ÉØ„Éº„ÇØ„ÅØ**testcontainers‰ª•‰∏ä**„ÅÆÊ©üËÉΩ„ÇíÊèê‰æõ„Åó„Åæ„ÅôÔºö

### ‚úÖ ÂèØËÉΩ„Å™„Åì„Å®Ôºàtestcontainers„Å®ÂêåÁ≠â‰ª•‰∏äÔºâ

#### 1. **Ëá™ÂãïÁöÑ„Å™„É©„Ç§„Éï„Çµ„Ç§„ÇØ„É´ÁÆ°ÁêÜ**
```nix
testScript = ''
  # Ëá™ÂãïËµ∑Âãï
  server.start()
  server.wait_for_unit("myapp.service")
  
  # „ÉÜ„Çπ„ÉàÂÆüË°å
  server.succeed("curl localhost:8080")
  
  # Ëá™Âãï„ÇØ„É™„Éº„É≥„Ç¢„ÉÉ„ÉóÔºàÊòéÁ§∫ÁöÑ„Å™Ë®òËø∞‰∏çË¶ÅÔºâ
'';
```

#### 2. **„Éù„Éº„ÉàÁÆ°ÁêÜ„ÅÆÂÆåÂÖ®Ëá™ÂãïÂåñ**
```nix
testScript = ''
  # „Éù„Éº„ÉàÈñãÊîæ„ÇíÂæÖÊ©üÔºàÁï™Âè∑„ÅÆÁÆ°ÁêÜ‰∏çË¶ÅÔºâ
  server.wait_for_open_port(8080)
  
  # Ë§áÊï∞„Çµ„Éº„Éì„Çπ„Åß„ÇÇË°ùÁ™Å„Å™„Åó
  db.wait_for_open_port(5432)
  api.wait_for_open_port(3000)
'';
```

#### 3. **„Éó„É≠„Çª„ÇπÁõ£Ë¶ñ„ÅÆÊäΩË±°Âåñ**
```nix
testScript = ''

## ÂÆüË°åÂÜÖÂÆπ
0. Á¶ÅÊ≠¢‰∫ãÈ†ÖÁ¢∫Ë™ç: `bin/docs/conventions/prohibited_items.md`
1. **ÂºïÊï∞„ÉÅ„Çß„ÉÉ„ÇØ**

2. **ÁèæÂú®‰ΩçÁΩÆ„ÅÆÂèñÂæó**
   - `tmux display-message -p '#{window_index}.#{pane_index}'`„ÅßÁèæÂú®„ÅÆwindow.pane„ÇíÂèñÂæó
   - ‰æã: 3.0 ‚Üí window 3„ÅÆpane 0„Å´„ÅÑ„Çã„Åì„Å®„ÇíÁ¢∫Ë™ç
3. **ÈÄÅ‰ø°ÂÖà„ÅÆÊ§úË®º**
   - ÊåáÂÆö„Åï„Çå„ÅüpaneÁï™Âè∑„ÅåÁèæÂú®„ÅÆwindowÂÜÖ„Å´Â≠òÂú®„Åô„Çã„ÅãÁ¢∫Ë™ç

   - ÊåáÂÆö„Åï„Çå„Åüpane„ÅåÁèæÂú®„ÅÆpane„Å®Âêå„ÅòÂ†¥Âêà„ÅØ„Ç®„É©„Éº
4. **„Çø„Çπ„ÇØ„ÇíÈÄÅ‰ø°**
   - ÊåáÂÆö„Åï„Çå„Åüwindow.pane„Å´„Çø„Çπ„ÇØ„ÇíÈÄÅ‰ø°
   - ‰ΩúÊ•≠„Éá„Ç£„É¨„ÇØ„Éà„É™„ÇíËá™ÂãïË®≠ÂÆö
5. **ÈÄÅ‰ø°Âæå„ÅÆÂãï‰ΩúÁ¢∫Ë™ç**
   - ÈÄÅ‰ø°Êìç‰Ωú„ÅåÊúüÂæÖÈÄö„ÇäÂãï‰Ωú„Åó„Åü„Åì„Å®„ÇíÁ¢∫Ë™ç

## „Çø„Çπ„ÇØÈÄÅ‰ø°„Éï„Ç©„Éº„Éû„ÉÉ„Éà
```bash

  echo "‰æã: /tmux 1 \"„ÉÜ„Çπ„Éà„ÇíÂÆüË°å„Åó„Å¶\""

fi

# 2. ÁèæÂú®„ÅÆwindow.pane„ÇíÂèñÂæó
current_location=$(tmux display-message -p '#{window_index}.#{pane_index}')

# 3. paneÁï™Âè∑„ÅÆÊ§úË®º

### üîç ËøΩÂä†Ê§úË®é„Åô„Åπ„Åç„Éï„Çß„Éº„Ç∫

### üìà NixOS„ÉÜ„Çπ„Éà„ÅÆÊúâÂäπÊÄß„Éû„Éà„É™„ÇØ„Çπ

| „Éï„Çß„Éº„Ç∫ | Ë§áÈõëÂ∫¶ | OS‰æùÂ≠ò | NixOS„ÉÜ„Çπ„Éà‰æ°ÂÄ§ |

## CLI ‚Üí IPC/ServerÁßªË°å„ÅÆÊú¨Ë≥™ÁöÑÁêÜÁî±

### üéØ ÁßªË°åÁêÜÁî±„ÅÆÂàÜÈ°û

#### 1. **Ëµ∑Âãï„Ç≥„Çπ„Éà„ÅÆÂïèÈ°å**
```bash

$ time python app.py process  # 0.5ÁßíÔºàPythonËµ∑ÂãïÔºâ
$ time python app.py process  # 0.5ÁßíÔºà„Åæ„ÅüËµ∑ÂãïÔºâ

# Server: Ëµ∑Âãï„ÅØ‰∏ÄÂ∫¶„Å†„Åë
$ curl localhost:8080/process  # 0.01Áßí

**Áâπ„Å´Èáç„ÅÑ‰æã**Ôºö
- JVMÁ≥ªÔºàScala, KotlinÔºâ: Ëµ∑Âãï2-3Áßí
- Â§ßË¶èÊ®°„É¢„Éá„É´Ë™≠„ÅøËæº„Åø: 10Áßí‰ª•‰∏ä

#### 2. **Áä∂ÊÖã‰øùÊåÅ„ÅÆÂøÖË¶ÅÊÄß**
```python

# Server: Áä∂ÊÖã„Çí‰øùÊåÅ
class Server:

    def process(self, input):
        return self.model.predict(input)  # È´òÈÄü
```

#### 3. **‰∏¶Ë°åÂá¶ÁêÜ„ÅÆË¶ÅÊ±Ç**
```bash
# CLI: ‰∏¶ÂàóÂÆüË°å„ÅåÈùûÂäπÁéá
for file in *.txt; do
    python app.py process "$file" &  # „Éó„É≠„Çª„Çπ‰π±Á´ã
done

# Server: ÂäπÁéáÁöÑ„Å™‰∏¶Ë°åÂá¶ÁêÜ
# 1„Éó„É≠„Çª„Çπ„ÅßË§áÊï∞„É™„ÇØ„Ç®„Çπ„ÉàÂá¶ÁêÜ
```

#### 4. **„É™„ÇΩ„Éº„ÇπÂÖ±Êúâ**
```
CLIÂïèÈ°å:
- DBÊé•Á∂ö„Éó„Éº„É´‰∏çÂèØ
- „Ç≠„É£„ÉÉ„Ç∑„É•ÂÖ±Êúâ‰∏çÂèØ
- „É°„É¢„É™ÈáçË§á

Server/IPCËß£Ê±∫:
- „Ç≥„Éç„ÇØ„Ç∑„Éß„É≥„Éó„Éº„É´
- ÂÖ±Êúâ„Ç≠„É£„ÉÉ„Ç∑„É•

```

### üìä ÁßªË°åÂà§Êñ≠„Éû„Éà„É™„ÇØ„Çπ

| Êù°‰ª∂ | CLIÁ∂ôÁ∂ö | ServerÁßªË°å |
|-----|---------|-----------|
| Ëµ∑ÂãïÊôÇÈñì < 0.1Áßí | ‚úÖ | |
| Ëµ∑ÂãïÊôÇÈñì > 1Áßí | | ‚úÖ |
| Áä∂ÊÖã‰∏çË¶Å | ‚úÖ | |
| Áä∂ÊÖãÂøÖË¶Å | | ‚úÖ |
| ÂçòÁô∫ÂÆüË°å | ‚úÖ | |
| ÈÄ£Á∂öÂÆüË°å | | ‚úÖ |
| „É°„É¢„É™ < 10MB | ‚úÖ | |
| „É°„É¢„É™ > 100MB | | ‚úÖ |

### üí° ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÁöÑ„Å™ÁßªË°å„Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥

#### „Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥1: Unix SocketÔºàÊúÄÂ∞èÂ§âÊõ¥Ôºâ
```python
# ÁßªË°åÂâçÔºàCLIÔºâ

# ÁßªË°åÂæåÔºàIPCÔºâ

#### „Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥2: HTTP APIÔºàÊ®ôÊ∫ñÁöÑÔºâ
```python

# ÁßªË°åÂæåÔºàServerÔºâ

#### „Éë„Çø„Éº„É≥3: gRPCÔºàÈ´òÊÄßËÉΩÔºâ
```python

```

### üîÑ ÊÆµÈöéÁöÑÁßªË°åÊà¶Áï•

{

    # Phase 2: „Éè„Ç§„Éñ„É™„ÉÉ„ÉâÔºàËá™ÂãïÂà§ÂÆöÔºâ
    smart = pkgs.writeShellScript "smart" ''

    # Phase 3: ServerÂøÖÈ†à

```
